body:
# PR Summary

Remove the check in CanDoPathLookup for wildcard characters in the command, as it prevents a PATH search of the command if it contains wildcard characters.

Fixes #10997

comments.author: msftrncs
comments.body:
A test is now failing on Windows,  (Shouldn't it fail on MacOs and Linux too?)

```
Describing Use literal path first when executing scripts
  [-] 'Relative path that where module qualified syntax overlaps' should not execute 28ms
    Expected an exception, with FullyQualifiedErrorId 'CouldNotAutoLoadModule' to be thrown, but no exception was thrown.
    139:             { & $command } | Should -Throw -ErrorId $ExpectedErrorId
```

I actually don't understand why this test would succeed (produce an exception).  I think the wildcard was preventing it from working, and the exception thrown was misleading.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: @msftrncs If the syntax is not longer treated as a module qualified invocation, then the change is breaking.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: This probably doesn't fail on non-windows because of differences in handling of the file system.

comments.author: msftrncs
comments.body:
Its not that the syntax is no longer treated as module qualified …   if it hadn't been for the wildcard characters, it would have executed …  if the actual path had not been found, PowerShell would have still checked for modules, but an existing file will be executed if it is found.

I do not think this breaks anything.

In the test, the file path is `subFolder\[test1].ps1`. 

The test for this kind of path appears to occur in the same section as `$env:PATH`, so when the code I removed previously flagged this path as `WildcardCharacters`, this prevented this path from testing for `DirectorySeparator`.  Under `DirectorySeparator` the path would be tested as a relative path to a file.  With the fix, this now works as it should.

Had the file been `subFolder\test1.ps1`, this test would also have failed, because the file would have executed, since it would have flagged as `DirectorySeparator`.

comments.author: TravisEz13
